subject: Re: [junit] a question about abstract/parameterised tests
msgSnippet: ... It s English. Perhaps rather more tersely punctuated than desirable for easy parsing ... ... Yes. Specifically I don t want to have to write out
messageBody:
On Thursday 07 August 2003 02:19, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> >So said Chris Dollin on 2003-08-05 --------------------

> >Erm ... no, that's not it, quite. Apologies for unclear writing (perhaps,
> >unclear thinking ...)
>
> It happens.
>
> >I want to write a method M which given a class C which is supposed
> >to implement interface I will return a suite which runs the abstract test
> >cases ATC for I with respect to the implementation C. I happens to be
> >Graph and the C's are implementations of Graph and there are enough
> >C's that writing out explicit subclasses of ATC for each C is a pain.
> >
> >This makes it easy for the writers of the different C's to run the
> >abstract test cases.
>
> With the greatest love and respect, that first sentence does not appear to
> be English.

It's English. Perhaps rather more tersely punctuated than desirable for easy
parsing ...

> You have an abstract test case AbstractTestGraph. There are a bunch of
> implementations (subclasses) of Graph. You want to be able to generate on
> the fly test cases for each implementation (subclass) of Graph.

Yes. Specifically I don't want to have to write out essentially the same code
once for each test subclass; the concrete test class differ only in their names
(incidental, although useful when they fail ...) and in the class of object they
instantiate (some subclass of Graph).

> If that is what you want, then it shouldn't be that hard. Create a
> TestSuite object consisting of dynamic subclasses of AbstractTestGraph,
> each of which overrides makeGraph() to answer its particular implementation
> of Graph. As I wrote, dynamic invocation handlers should do the job.

It's generating those dynamic subclasses of AbstractTestGraph that's the
problem for me. Am I missing something in the reflection API?

> >What's important is not to be able to create a suite of them all (although
> >that might be nice), but to be able to trivially able to create a suite
> > for each one to be plugged into the locally appropriate test-cases.
>
> You want to generate code? or generate the implementation at runtime?

The latter - as an implementation of "write concise code which does the
job".

> >[When I say "suite" am I being sloppy? I really mean "a test that runs
> >lots of tests".]
>
> Tests don't run tests. TestRunners run tests.

I really mean "a test that when run results in the running of lots of tests."

> >So far as I can tell, it would be easy in Java if classes nested inside
> >methods
> >were allowed to be public. I suspect the restriction was not reviewed when
> >they added reflection to the official language ...
>
> They are if they are class-level (static).

Yes, but then they're not nested inside methods, which rather loses the point
of parametisation. Hmm. Perhaps I'm missing a trick with non-static inner
classes. (The trouble with dynamic inner classes being that their constructors
won't match the pattern expected by junit ...)

Will cogitate. Much other stuff to do as well. Thanks for prodding.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
